reviewText:
I'm going to come back here and update this review. A lot has changed relatively fast, as it typically is in MMOs, so I feel like my old review is a little inaccurate. My first review of this game was posted slightly after 4th Jobs were added if my memory serves, and the game is just... so different now.

First, I still recommend it. It's a very new player friendly MMO, and while that annoys me personally, I get the push to make games like this more rewarding to a new player. It's a great experience overall and the story translation is getting better bit by bit. The localization team is also getting a lot better about pushing updates through at a more timely pace - if you knew how long it took to get Season 2, much less the episodes of Season 2 vs Season 3 and then almost immediately Counterattack and Vagrant, you would think the localization team was replaced by gods.

So, what changed so much for me to think I need to come back and update a year and a half old review? Everything. Literally everything. When I wrote this review at first, there were six classes, the most recent being Soul... Lord? Master? Edgy Wizard. It was a pretty strong class with few noticable downsides, a stark contrast to the second most recent class at the time - Engineer, which is a class made of downsides and few noticeable postives.

Fast forward to now. We were treated to the introduction of a new class - the Card Master. Unleash your inner YuGiOh and throw playing cards at your enemies to destroy the forces of evil... and sometimes capture the forces of evil and use them to destroy the forces of evil! ... So yeah, less like YuGiOh and more like Pokemon. Maybe if the two met. Sounds like it would make a great anime. This class came along with Season 3, which brought tremendous change to the game's basic systems, simplifying almost every aspect of gameplay, and bringing out quite a few gripes from me personally.

First and most notably, the weapons system was overhauled. Instead of having unique weapons that you can find from various enemies, each with specific stats to help encourage a particular playstyle, you get two generic classes of weapon - basic, and (S). Only a fool would ever use the basic weapons as they come with no bonus stats, never drop with an option (enchant) on them, and are significantly less powerful than the (S) weapons. Why weapons that aren't (S) weapons exist is well beyond my comprehension, because it doesn't add the same depth of gameplay that, say, having ten different swords to choose from did. Sure - towards endgame, everyone just uses the same powerful weapons from endgame dungeons, but there was a certain charm in seeing lower level players (and sometimes higher leveled players) choose a weapon because of its slightly unorthodox stats.

Weapons weren't the only thing - class specific armor was removed entirely until level 180, forcing every class to equip themselves the same and reap generic stamina/strength benefits. It's worth noting that since luck has a semi-unknown effectiveness cap, there's not much point in stacking in, and since only three of now eight classes use magic primarily, it's sensible to just protect mages until level 180, but having to choose what armor you like the best based on the same principle of diversity that weapons once presented just feels better, like you're actually doing something, you know? An even bigger problem (for me personally, your mileage may vary) is how good the generic (S) armor is. They outshine the instance dungeon armor hands down, and protect even the squishiest classes against otherwise challenging boss monsters and huge mobs of enemies. To get the same challenge from low level instance dungeons that newer players would get in Season 1, they'd have to take their armor off entirely. The incredibly powerful weapons would probably still end the fight too fast for the boss to have a fair chance, though.

Simplification isn't always bad though. Potions no longer come in health, sp, and combination, and instead only come in combination, and they heal huge. As a Savior main (tremendous HP), HP potions never did anything for me, but now I can get a full heal off of just one potion. Yeah, it's easier than it once was, but it's a welcome change to have potions that heal enough to satisfy every class' needs. Crafting was simplified as well, but it's a bit more double edged - it's easier to gather materials to make weapons, armor, accessories, and food, but crafting has been made generic - no one needs to find a refiner to get them to make cloak kits to take to an accessory crafter and have them make cloaks - you can do it all yourself now. Again, this is just a personal gripe because I prefer slightly more complex systems, and in the end, it really does make crafting a more enjoyable experience. You also level it up by paying in game currency instead of having to craft 10 billion worthless items.

As it stands now, you might as well consider yourself new until you hit level 170, and then the game actually starts. The problem now, though, is how much of a sharp increase there is in difficulty past that point. Dungeons go from extremely easy to unfair just like that, and for new players who aren't used to the steady climb in difficulty of Season 1 (and to a lesser extent, Season 2), it seems really sudden. Even to someone like me who's been playing for four years, the endgame dungeons seem poorly balanced to favor players who enchant their gear to get overpowered stats - and honestly these dungeons are all but impossible to complete without overpowered enchants. It seems like a poor choice on the developer's end to balance these dungeons to challenge the players who purposefully made the rest of the game too easy for themselves, instead of balancing the difficulty towards the middle of the road players who were taught by the game that they'll make it if they stay dilligent.

Just to provide an example - the first true endgame dungeon is Velfa Library. The boss does almost exclusive magic damage (which most armors and classes do not defend against), but the generic mobs in the dungeon have reasonable HP and while they hit hard, they don't hit super hard. This dungeon is a reasonable challenge, and is balanced well for the level you're supposed to visit it at.

Meanwhile, one of the newer dungeons, Road of Dream, is full of generic mobs that hit like a freight train and have health on par with the boss of Velfa Library, each. If you haven't come geared to hit for 100,000 at minimum and/or take thousands of damage per hit, you won't last here for more than a minute.

I wouldn't complain about the unreal difficulty if anything in the game up to that point prepared you for it, but nothing comes close. Like I said, you go from wow that was a great dungeon and a real challenge" in Forgotten Garden

reviewText:
LaTale: 2D platformer MMORPG
8/10

Having played this game on and off since 2009, I believe I can write a fair review for it.  LaTale is not perfect, but what free to play game is?  I will say that it is a very fun 2D platformer MMORPG.  The music is great, the artwork is beautiful, the skills are flashy, the classes are not one-dimensional and most of them actually require a decent bit of variety to play them to their full potential.  I have tried Maple Story, but the gameplay was just too simplistic and boring to hook me.  LaTale has hooked me due to its more in-depth gameplay.

Now, a lot of people may have reservations of picking up a free-to-play game, thinking it's pay to win.  This is not the case with LaTale.  Will you need to spend a few bucks to get started, like with an auto looting pet?  Yes.  But here's the nice thing about LaTale: most of the cash shop items are tradeable, so you can get those items by playing the game and trading with other players.

If you're looking for a fun, pretty, cute, silly and exciting 2D rpg experience, then LaTale is the game for you!

reviewText:
I have about 5 hours logged onto the game, so this may be pre-emptive, but I'd like to say something about it so far.

Likes:
- Great artwork!
The game itself is beautiful and it feels unique. The world itself is unique and so are the characters. It seems like there is a lot to see in this game.
- Music is very enjoyable.
Every area has its own music, which tells me that they put A LOT of time and effort into this game. Being a musician myself, I know how much effort goes into 1 piece of music.  All of the music i've encountered so far has a very warm sound to it and sounds very happy. That ties in with the friendly atmosphere of the game.
- Friendly environment
Like it advocates, this game has a very friendly atmosphere attached to it, which is extremely desirable for MMOs these days. One of the biggest problems in MMOs is the community in most games. While I wouldn't say that this is an extremely populated game, it does attract friendly people. I've not seen any slander or inappropriate text in all chat and everyone seems to be willing to help out.

Dislikes:
- Strange Controls:
It's nothing you can't get used to, but double-tapping to run gets pretty tedious. The original hotkeys are also sort of strange in comparison to other MMOs. You can set them yourself, but initially, will be a little confusing.

- Quest UI:
The quest UI is a little strange in that, it has the story description of the quest on the first tab and then another tab for the specific quest description/reward. It's not a terrible feature, but it's not quite convenient either. You always have to click over to see the specifics. A quest bar on the side will pop up also to help you track your quests, but clicking on them doesn't bring up the quest in the quest log, so that's also not very convenient.

- Quests are a bit boring:
I normally love the grind on MMOs, but it just doesn't seem too fun in this game. You collect a quest to kill certain mobs and then after turning it in, you are asked to kill them again to collect items from them, and sometimes even asked to go back a 3rd time to kill the same mob to get a different quest item. It seems a bit too tedious.

- Not much difficulty:
It's pretty easy. I guess the first 20 levels of any MMO can be described the same way, but I mean, I didn't really have to try too hard to be good at my class.

- Limited Battle Customization:
Maybe I was spoiled with WoW, but it seems like the battle customization is pretty low. I've gotten a few new skills and chose where to put my skill points in my own order, but they are still capped by levels. I suppose that's fair, but in terms of having unique skills, you kind of just put the points in your own order, but you're still dictated by the level system. I'm sure this won't be a problem in later levels, but for now, it does make leveling not very fun.

All in all, a pretty good game, but I couldn't see myself investing a lot of my time into this game. I'm glad to have gotten the experience so far and will probably grind a bit more just to see if my opinion changes. I wouldn't recommend the game as a long term game, but I would recommend it if you're looking for a friendly place to game,

0 playtime because I've played this game a lot off steam. Like, more than I'd like to admit. Probably 1000+ hours worth, or somewhere around that number. I was there when the closed beta for both OGP and Aeria games held this little treasure, and I was there when there were just 4 initial classes, and you had to get to 80 to rank up. Back when puzzle pieces were locked behind a paywall.

Needless to say, I've played this game a lot. Not so much anymore, what with real-world responsibility weighing down on me, but I can tell you for a fact that this MMO is definitely worth your time.

The animations are fluid, and the way combat works is very different from Maple Story, and I believe it looks a thousand times nicer too. Whereas in Maple you'll usually stick to a spot, throw a couple skills out at enemies, jump around to avoid an enemy or something then repeat, Latale has you constantly spamming your rather nice looking skills, stick-then move basis where enemies go down relatively quickly to  your power in a gratifying and enjoyable way. And the game rewards you for your quick movements and your quick attack chains with a hit counter (Which, by the way, increases your exp and ely awards the higher it is).

Since it's many updates and balances, Latale has a total of 6 initial classes (since I last checked), the 4 main ones (Warrior, Knight, Wizard, Explorer) splits off into two paths each, while the other two (Engineer, Soul breaker) just change into their own new thing. These changes happen at level 40 (Used to be 80, that being a long and arduous journey to get there), and once you do get to that golden number, just about everything changes. Whatever class you chose to go into at that level gets massive buffs, new skills, sometimes even new playstyles (Like Engineer --> Meister, go from wielding a suitcase into a pilotable mecha. No, nothing in that sentence is a typo.), which radically either changes the game, or sets you on a new course with new skills and powers to try out on the masses of enemies just awaiting to die. And the class upgrades beyond that do just the same.

Lately, the game seems to have gotten a pay-to-win vibe to it, which is very discouraging to new players. But most of the items you can buy in the item shop, you can attain in-game through either some work or some of the many events that OGP seems to like to throw it's players. Stuff like the fashion items and the auto-loot pets, along with some other key items that makes life super easy is locked behind that paywall. It's fairly annoying, but the game's entertainment value for what it does and it's wild ride more than makes up for it. Plus, if you do so choose to spend money, you get some relatively good value for what you spend (Take advantage of the sales!).

Unfortunately, like almost all MMOs do, it starts to get grindy once you start getting to 70+. Fairly late in the game, and at the point where you've already accomplished so much, and there's much more to go, that you'll either want to keep going, or you'll start to fall out and just play once in a while. I'll leave this particular part up to you to decide if you'd want to keep going from there. But even if you do play up until then, it'll be the best ~70 levels you've ever played in an MMO, I guarantee it.

Not gonna lie, there is some pretty bad localization in this. They've had over a few years to get it right, and they still haven't, even some of the NPCs that have been in the game since day 1 of closed beta. If you're a grammar nazi, or if seeing silly sentences turns you off, be warned. There's some story to the game, and unless you have an open mind or you're totally cool with skipping all the dialogue and text boxes on the quests, you'll get annoyed quickly. There's some untranslated items sprinkled around too, though not nearly as common.


To sum it all up, Latale is a fantastic ride, with it's combat feeling fresh and exciting with each new skill and class one tries out, and continues to do so until the later levels. While the game is slightly pay-to-win, it's largely negligible unless you want to take a bunch of shortcuts or have that autolooting pet. The localization is at best passable, and at worst downright terrible, but if you can look beyond that, latale is a fantastic MMO to sink your teeth into.


And no, it's not a Maple Story clone. IMO, I think Maple could take some lessons from Latale.

La Tale is a fun 2d side-scrolling mmorpg.  It has a cute artstyle, but the underlying game mechanics are a lot more complex than the appearance would lead you to believe.  There's tons of stuff to do in the game, from questing, to gathering up items and cards to build a codex of items/monsters, to instance dungeons that need eight players to do properly.

The recent season three update has vastly improved the game with lots of quality-of-life improvements, as well as making it significantly easier to get to high levels and reach end game.  The quest rewards have been significantly enlarged, making leveling, especially in lower levels quite simple.  Just do your quests and the levels will follow up till about level 100 when it starts to slow down.  (This slow down is temporary, as once you get another ten levels or so the amount of quests pick back up till around level 170/180.)

Give it a try, it's free and a lot of fun.  I've been playing it since the closed beta in 2008, and made a new account on Steam just to have it on my account.  (I'll admit to wanting the badge too.)

reviewText:
I would like to start by saying that we all have our own preferences when it comes to gaming, so never 100% go off of reviews.

Anyway, this game is indeed Free-To-Play. You do not need to spend money in game, as of yet, to progress in the game. However, I instantly fell in love with this game, within the first 3 hours of gameplay, I spent a small bit of money on it. £6 ($10). With this, I managed to get an awesome gothic themed outfit, an adorable pet and some special items which lets me finish my quest without having to speak to the quest-giver. Which I think is fairly reasonable considering other games I've played, the tokens have cost tons more and you can't get nearly as much as this. The basic armour is particularly fashionable and not an eye-sore. The weapons are also considerably badass-looking. I'm currently using a Staff (I'm a Wizard) which I think looks a bit like one of Sailor Moon's weapons.

Items are relatively easy to retrieve via looting, however most drops are junk items - the game tells you this in a little note in the item's description. Lag is extremely minimal. I may have d/ced from the server once or twice in the course of 12 hours. The game has multiple channels with about 7 or so servers within each, which really helps the lag spread out and, well, not lag.

One thing that people will complain about is that this is a side-scroller. I am telling you now, it feels nothing like one of those. I know that sounds stupid considering it is in fact a side-scroller. But, it just doesn't really feel like one. The graphics are cute and very well done. I applaud the pixel artists and background artists that have put the effort into their job, it really shows. The music as well, extraordinarily beautiful. None of it is a slow, short and painful loop. Which I yet again commend, it never grates on your ears. Going back to the graphics, the attacks are fabulous. I feel as though some attacks aren't pixelated. The fire attacks I currently have don't look pixelated, which adds reality to the game. Some of the animations for the attacks are utterly adorable. For example, 'Bubble Bubble', your character uses a bubble blower to blow some bubbles. And afterwards their eyes go all wide and shiny. I love it. And something similar for 'Ice Spear', I think that's what it's called. The monsters are also very well pixelated, some of the pixelling in this game is gorgeous, and is enough to make you want to play.

This game has a combo system which lets you get attacks in quicker. All moves are AOE, apart from your regular attack which makes mobbing all the more easy. I play an RPG where a mage has extremely limited AOE moves, painful I tell you. As you increase the combo, you'll get more exp. Levelling up seems to be easy. I'm already level 30, but the levels do go ridiculously high, I think I've seen a level 192?

What I've met of the players, they all seem to be English and friendly. Most higher levels are normally snobbish and frown upon lower levels, but they help you out and treat you as an equal, as it should be in all games.

The quests are very generic. Kill this, loot this, talk to this person. Which is one of the downsides to the game. I've already strayed from the quests as it is due to this. But I think most games are like this. Everyone eventually abandons the quests and goes off on their own. I think I've still got a level 3 quest there someone. Along with level 10s, 22s etc. You actually don't need the quests, however they do give you quite a bit of experience and 'Ely'. Which is the game's currency, much like most games is gold.

The pets in this game don't attack. The highest level for them seems to be 20. Apparently, which I had to find out from a higher level player because the help guide wasn't much help, the egg hatches at level 5, the pet matures at level 10 and it can change its appearance or something. I can't fully recall. Different pets have different abilities. My current pet can open a shop at level 5 and at level 10 it will increase my magic and luck. When your pet reaches 100% exp, you must go and buy a supplement to level it. There are 4 different supplements which increase in price. Lvl 1-4 which is 10k; Lvl 5-9 which is 30k or so and it increases accordingly. I think it eventually gets to 100k or something ridiculous like that. The first pet you get through a quest is useless, cannot hatch and has no abilities whatsoever. I would say it's there to look pretty, but it doesn't even do that. It's an egg with wings, called 'Handsome Egg'. Utterly useless.

To sum it all up, I would strongly recommend this game. But, remember my opening statement - 'I would like to start by saying that we all have our own preferences when it comes to gaming, so never 100% go off of reviews.'

Mine your heart out.
Fish forever!

Chill out.
Be a merchant.

There's so much more freedom in this game than most other 2d MMORPGS...

Because after having seen this and having never played it before, despite having an OGplanet account, I decided to download it from Steam to give it a try. Yup.
You legitimately cannot play this game through steam without making a brand new OGplanet account through steam.

That is why this game can't be recommended. The idea of such a massive gaping hole in the ease of access, and the hassle it requires. Maybe for new players who don't mind making an account for OGplanet, then it really doesn't matter. But its still a rather silly 'release' on steam, and quite honestly, shouldn't be released like that to begin with, regardless of any kind of company-side issues.

Again, this is just my review for 'La Tale on Steam'. Not La Tale itself. Which I can't play without going to download the game -again- on OGplanet itself so that I can use my existing account.

reviewText:
A fair business model and fun action make this Korean MMO a pretty fun time.

You start off with three character slots, which is pretty fair as additional ones are around $10 USD. The action is crisp and the controls are responsive, even during the very occasional lag. Classes are fun to play and varied between each other, and the stage areas are varied as well. The community is relatively helpful, and the world is beautifully done.

The main con is the fact that it is /poorly/ translated. Don't think about getting any useful plot points out of the story, it's muddled and confusing at best.

If you enjoy beating the crap out of adorable things with satisfying gameplay and controls, then this game is for you.

reviewText:
La Tale Review
Finally got around to write this review, this game is one of the few MMOs I actually like.
Don't judge by my play time here.
I've played for years on the OGPlanet Launcher.

Story 	The story is rather simplistic.
The story is centered around Iris Reviere and her party.
She is an explorer with numerous adventures who made a name for herself.
But one day, she suddenly disappeared without notice and no one knows where she actually is.
She is the person that brings you in the world of La Tale and after that you are left on your own devices as you follow through her footsteps and in the process making it into your very own journey.
That's it for the story I guess, there alot more since the story is really big for an MMO but this is just a summary of what you should expect.

Gameplay	The gameplay in La Tale is great.
The combat especially.
It's dynamic, varied and fun.

There are plenty of weapons to use depending on your class and each one has alot of combo variety. Some are more focused on supporting fellow party members instead of hitting hard.
Some focus on dealing damage with your spells and actives while others focus on raw damage straight from your basic attacks and tankiness.
There are alot of classes since every base class can go in 2 directions - either an upgrade of his defeault class or go on a totally different route with a completely new weapon.

Forgot to mention.
The game can get grindy depending on the class you are using
If you use Card Master or Wanderer you will have a great experience as they level up extremely fast but with other classes you will level up slower.

The game's level capacity is 250 if I am not mistaken. You could probably reach it in a month depending on the time you spent on this game.

Graphics	The graphics are gorgeous in my opinion.
Cute anime graphics with great pixelated art and particle effects.
Attention to detail in artwork is alot and is really appreciated.

Customization	Now, customization is really varied... that is if you are willing to pay ofcourse,
You can still look unique without really paying but it will require hard work so you can farm enough Ely - the ingame free currency in order to buy Astro items from the market and other people.
However 90% of the Astro items are purely cosmetics and do not make you stronger at all.
Astro is the premium currency.

Community	This game has the friendliest community I've seen in a game.
The game advertises is self as the friendliest MMO and it does not lie.
Every single person I have met her - I have had great time with them.
Telling each other dirty jokes or grinding together while

Music	Music is a joy to listen to, every track is beautiful and has it's own atmosphere.
The music is the thing that makes La Tale feel like La Tale.
It makes the game feel unique. (Despite being similar to MapleStory, lol... but judging how MapleStory is faring these days... you're better off with La Tale instead).

reviewText:
This game is not that horrible. Its for people who pull up youtube videos while leveling their guy up, not so much for people looking for a rich gameplay and story experience. Not that the gameplay and story is bad, actually its pretty good.

Unlike Maplestory where if you just touch an enemy it registers damage, enemies have attack animations. This makes a huge difference because it allows you to dodge the attack and counter. People may think that this does not make such a difference, but it does especially when there is a combo system which rewards you with money and exp for high combos. You even get a light attack, strong attack, jumpings attacks, blocks, and more. However, leveling and killing certain monsters (ones that don't stagger) are much more difficult, but fun.

English translations are AWFUL like REALLY ♥♥♥♥ING BAD. Some npcs and items just have random symbols instead of words, however they are few and somewhat far between. Skills are pretty cool looking and interesting, however due to the lack of a LaTale youtube community, you will have to guess on what the skills does based on its description, which is sort of bad due to the translation errors.

There is a fashion shop and some items do give you stat bonuses, but the cool thing about this game is that you can actually pay for special points (not cash shop points) using in game money to buy those items for a limited time (however you can keep buying them). Also due to the amazing amount of events and dedicated staff, you can actually get permanent cash shop items and stuff just for free!

Now the main downside of this game is the really bad tutorial. They really dont tell you very much and its a lot better to find a high level character and ask him or her for help.

All in all, 7/10. Get it if you like to watch youtube videos on the side while doing something somewhat productive.
If you say Maplestory is better, this game is much harder and has better staff, but somewhat smaller community.

reviewText:
La Fail - A Broken Unplayable Mess.

This game is down right unplayable. If you even try to use the Keyboard and mouse to play, it will CRASH on you.
If you try to use the Gamepad, you will notice that you're playing an MMO solo as you can absolutely NEVER chat to anyone. Because the moment you do, the game will crash. Doesn't matter when you hit a button either.

If you're an old player coming back to it because it's on Steam now, avoid the steam version as you will be forced to make a new account anyway.

Other than the broken unplayable mess, La Tale is an simply another attempt at a MapleStory knock off (otherwise known as a Clone). However, it has slower gameplay and more sluggish feeling attacks. While I do enjoy the Combo-like system it has and can make for great burst kills, that's pretty much all there is to it. There is more open ended character choices as some characters can have 4 different ways to be built; ultimately they will be lackluster as they aren't made solely with one thing in mind.

It's better than Wind Slayer but far from being better than MapleStory. 5.5/10

reviewText:
If your personal fantasy is to have your eyes assaulted by what can only be described as a unicorn wetdream on LSD, then you'll probably enjoy this 'game'.
I use the term 'game' lightly, as my experience can only be described as initially being hand-held like a bald-headed child with some sort of mental disorder through the most basic of tasks (walking left-to-right, climbing a ladder, not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ yourself), only to find myself afterwards being thrown head-first into a moshpit of anime girls and boys, with seizure inducing fancy effects. After being treated like a limp-footed mental case, to be then thrown into one of a million brightly coloured menus, characters, obscure quests and overly-attached Power Rangers, to say that I was confused and overwhelmed would be an understatement. Imagine listening to anything by Skrillex without being on some sort of party-drug.

Between the hundreds of anime look-a-likes forming a blockade between you and making sense of where you actually are, the glowing icons, incomprehensible menus and quests, the frankly bizarre dialogue and the somewhat disturbing music (clealy the result of multi-generation JRPG inbreeding), you'll find yourself wanting to commit seppuku at an alarming rate.

If you're 8 years old, a brony, or perhaps someone who enjoys self-torture, then this will probably be an epileptic treat. If you want to keep your sanity or dignity intact, then stay away.

Honestly, what is the point in putting your game onto Steam to try and attract a new userbase if you're not going to fix the glaring problems that this game has had since launch?

Still laggy? Yep!
Still terrible resolution options? Yep!
Still that horrible input delay where it feels like your character is doing something half a second after you instruct them to? Yep!
Still running really rubbish events that are in no way designed to reward the userbase, but are instead designed to try and claw money from you unless you're willing to pump an ungodly amount of hours into the game? Yep!
Still an absolute chore of a grind? Yep! (even Maple Story's devs realised at one point that the grind was ridiculous and adjusted accordingly)

Oh wait, I'm guessing that finally you're realising that the game is all but dead, there are far better alternatives out there (ElSword, Dragonica, Maple Story), and this is a last chance to try and scrape some cash. Honestly wouldn't waste your time folks, with all the problems that have persisted through the game's entire history, the only way you could possibly enjoy this to any extent is if it's your first ever MMO Platformer/RPG, or you've got more money than sense.

Only positive thing I can say about this game is that it does have some damn nice spritework. Unfortunately, that's all it has.

Avoid/10

reviewText: La Tale is a simple side-scrolling game most comparable to Maplestory back in its younger years. You start out by picking one of the classic RPG classes, which then can be advanced into an even better class at level 80. The quests are simple; kill 'x' amount of monsters or get this item from so-and-so or go to this NPC. It isn't that difficult to level up in, and the storyline is easy to understand despite the grammar lost in translation. Despite the massive amount of grinding done, it isn't that painful and the game makes it relaxing. The quirky yet colorful graphics are anime/manga-like, and the colors for equipment and such aren't gender restricted. I highly reccomend that everyone reading this review should try the game for at least five to ten minutes; even if it's not your cup of tea.

After around an hour's worth of play, La Tale puts a lot of interesting elements on the table, makes questing easy and in no way frusterating, has great music, and makes me sad that MegaMan Online was cancelled.  I'll continue.

La Tale is a 2D side-scrolling MMORPG by Actoz Soft, a rather unknown company.  The first aspect that La Tale does right is not losing the player's attention in the first five minutes.  Many MMO's start out with some lame backstory, a bunch of tutorials, and a year's worth of starter quests before you even get into the actual game.  La Tale gives you a tutorial, some quests, and throws you in.  No bull.  And I like that.  Gameplay is divided into combat and platforming.  Platforming isn't too difficult, but adds a much needed twist in the enviroments.  La Tale's UI is not a cluster-eff, and isn't confusing.  The art style is sweet, very anime-like, and I'm fine with that.  Controls will take getting used to, but there not too hard to learn.  The music in La Tale is amazingly good, it sounds like some of Capcom's retro tracks, and some of Sonic CD's lesser known hits, but also sounds like it's own style.  It is very rhythmic, and Ireally enjoyed listening to it.

At the end of the day, La Tale is a breakaway from the traditional MMO setup, and it's really good.  I'm sad that MegaMan Online was never created because of how great this game is.  Even if you can't into traditional MMO's, you should at least try this one.  It's a nice change of pace in a saturated market.

reviewText:
Edit: (03/03/16) The latency has become a horrible problem and is starting to hinder the ability to play.

I have played this game off and on for years now with long periods of down time. I loved the structure of the game, but the implementation of the way it all worked had always felt wrong or slightly off. Getting back into the game, things feel smoother and as they should be. Maps flow excellently now, quests are considerably easier to understand, leveling up is not a total chore right from the get-go, making money isn't an exhausting issue, many things seem to be in nice places with more proper labels. Compared to what the game is now, LaTale felt much, much more unorganized when I last played. The classes are still flashy and fun to play, and I see some skill animation changes have come around too which is really nice. (Warrior's heavy attack is not some clunky slow swing now)

All in all, LaTale is getting to a point where it honestly should have been at a long time. But hey, better late than never. Give this game a shot if you enjoy(ed) Maplestory.

Edit: Okay, I do see what other people mean about the translations being poor. They definitely need to be revised for proper English. It looks like some Asian kids with a terrible understanding of English wrote more than half of the scripts for the NPC's. One character even says something in a different language but spelled with English letters. That's just...massively stupid... I believe that's called Singlish? idk, needs to be fixed.

reviewText:
Things I like:

Cute pixel art
cute monsters
cute characters
Cute backgrounds
Cute music
Cute idea
Cute costumes/items/ weapons/pets/ etc
I think the whole world is very pretty and imaginative. It's a nice escape for a free game.

I think the leveling system is fine and fair and the little extra thingys you can do on the side (such as the Star Eating Tree) are nice too.

You dont have to pay any real money to win, but you cant get anything fun (such as costumes or guilds or pets that last forever) without money. So you arent going to look as flashy as the other players.

Things I dont like:

You can't reuse an old, deleted name.

You have to pay for things with real money that some games do for free (such as make a guild, and have a permanent pet (such as Aura Kingdom) )

Sometimes I feel like the game is micromanaged too much as a form of making money. Such as, you buy a piece to buy a piece to get a thing to get a thing that only lasts for fifteen minutes. Instead of this, I want stable, lasting items that give you a long, lasting rewards for your hard work. Not a 10% speed bonus for 10 minutes. I dont want that crap.

Literally there is like a price for everything, and usually they are not worth the money. Why would I buy something with my real money that will only last for 15 days? Seriously, cut the time limit crap.

The english is really bad at some parts, and makes the story seem really stupid. Literally I have no idea what the story is.

(I'm sure if they tried to fix the english, it would be a lot better.)

NPC's have really dumb names sometimes, and say really dumb, nonsensical stuff.

Some classes arent as powerful as others. And some arent as fun to play or are as cool looking (maybe im just biased),  I think all of the classes should be more fleshed out in some ways.

Oh, also! Final one! I think all of the classes should have a unique background story. I think one or two of the newer classes have one, but none of the others do. It makes me not want to play them.

Okay, I'm done. I'm finally done.
